so let's get started um right so data transfer happens when you
cross boundaries in the network uh different activities may may drive network communication across
those boundaries and that communication is measured and in some cases charged
so in terms of our network since you've come to watch this
presentation today you are likely familiar um with the concept of regions and
availability zones in a plus cloud um so currently our network is made up of 26
geographic regions and 84 availability zones uh one of the latest regions was
launched just recently in the last few weeks each region is made up of at least two
availability zones and usually more than that and most of the discussion today will be around
regions and availability zones so let's look at examples of how data
transfer occurs when workloads are deployed on aws so the primary way to get um data in or
out of aws is over the internet let's say you have a video file in your
s3 bucket um in one of the aws regions and let's say you're downloading that file directly
from s3 to your home laptop because the data needs to leave aws and
travel over the internet um you will then see that the transfer out charges on your bill and those charges were
those charges vary depending on the aws region note that uh
first 100 gigabytes of data transfer out per month is free
and is covered under three tier um well covered by limitations of free tier
and any data transfer into aws from the internet is also free of charge
um so if you decide to upload a large file into your s3 bucket for example uh
you will later be charged for storage for storing that data but you will not be charged for data transfer in
um now let's look at data transfer between aws regions one ec2 instances
for example in one region communicate with aws resources in
another region uh and it could be resources like s3 buckets or another ec2
instance we call this inter region data transfer and there is a per gigabyte charge
associated with that um it's about it's important to note that um we only charge
for the outbound side of the communication between two aws regions so for example if the resource in aws
region one on this diagram is on the left sends traffic to a resource in region 2
let's say on the right the charge is assessed at the region 1 on the left side
where communication was initiated and when the resource from region two is
then responding let's say or replying to a resource in region one then the charge will be assessed at the region two on
the on the right side uh this is important because this per gigabyte caused the rise by region
and we will see this later on the demo as well um another type of data transfer charges is
a regional or general type of data transfer is regional let's say there is an ec2 instance in
one availability zone that talks to an institute instance in another availability zone they are both
they are both part of the same region but they've crossed that ac boundary in
this case they incur inter az data transfer charges um that's charged in
both directions on a per gigabyte basis um i'll discuss this topic um
a little later in the presentation about essentially reducing your application
communication across ac boundaries is an important technique to reduce data transfer charges um try to build your
application so that the communication is contained within the single ac but then create multiple partitions of
that application across ics so you can provide the redundancy that your application needs um and note that
traffic uh within the same level availability zone is free if resources
communicate over private id and you will be charged per gigabyte both directions
if they use public ip um also data transfers um well yeah data transferred
between services like pc2 and other services like s3
rds or redshift and others um in the same availability zone is free so
for example if you have an application server on ec2 and you have a database on rds um and then
they are like in the same ability zone and they communicate with each other using private ap uh this traffic will
not be charged it will be free um so it's important to understand what's
driving your data transfer out to the internet uh well data transfer out charges to the internet
if you find you are using data transfer out for serving a lot of content to the internet uh you might want to
investigate a cloudfront service cloudfront still incurs data transfer
out cost for servicing content to the internet um but it may be cheaper uh
than directly from ec2 out to the internet plus you get the benefit of a better user experience um
by serving content from edge locations which are closer to your end users um
cloudfront also has free tier um and it's even better than ec2 so first one
terabyte of data transfer out per month is free and in terms of communication between
cloud front uh let's say well cloudfront is location and the origin uh or we call

um and last example let's say you need to get data to and from your data center uh

there is a data processing charge for data that is addressing or leaving aws

will not be charged it will be free uh so yeah in the majority of cases anything coming in to aws
uh or into your resources is free anything coming out is uh charged um
again unless it's within the same availability zone using private ips
